GMT 3513.course_description: Overview of Greek politics, society, and culture in the 20th century.

GMT 4110.course_description: Overview of major genres of Byzantine literature (Patristic literature, oratory, historiography, chronicle, hagiography, hymnography, epic poetry) from the years CE 330-1453.

GMT 4911.course_name: Undergraduate Research in Modern Greek Language and Literature
GMT 4911.course_description: Provides firsthand, supervised research. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application.

GRA 1831C.course_description: Introduces the contemporary graphic design praxis and its specializations through technologies and tools for collaboration, exploration, and production. In addition, emphasizes critical making and training to offer an overview of possibilities and develop an essential graphic design toolkit that considers access, equity, inclusion, and context. The goal is for students to fall in love with the field(s), the processes, and the possibilities.

GRA 4923C.course_description: Advanced study in graphic design and professional practices of design in business and multidisciplinary learning experiences. Students repeating this course will have demonstrated excellence during the first semester, been selected for their leadership abilities and assigned advanced roles in the studio environment.

GRA 4930.course_description: Advanced study of issues and topics in graphic design beyond those in the regular curriculum.

GRA 4940.course_description: 0-6 credits repeatable for credit. Graphic/communication design professional practice and related experience as defined by program guidelines.

GRE 1120.course_description: The basics of ancient Greek grammar, morphology, syntax and vocabulary.

GRE 1130.course_description: This course and its sequel, GRE 1131, constitute the basic sequence for development of overall skill in the language.

GRK 1130.course_description: This course and its sequel, GRK 1131, constitute the basic sequence for development of overall skill in the language.

GRW 3102.course_description: Studies representative texts from various periods of Greek literature.

GRW 3301.course_description: Selected plays of Aeschylus, Sophocles or Euripides.

GRW 4330.course_description: Translation and analysis of Greek lyric poetry, from Archilochus to Bacchylides.

GRW 4340.course_description: Translation and analysis of selections from Homer's Iliad and Odyssey.

GRW 4380.course_description: Translation and analysis of selections of Herodotus, Thucydides, Xenophon, and Plutarch.

GRW 4911.course_name: Undergraduate Research in Greek Language and Literature
GRW 4911.course_description: Provides firsthand, supervised research. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application.

HAI 2201.course_description: Continued concentration on conversation with added emphasis on reading and perspectives on issues related to the Haitian way of living.

HAI 3930.course_description: Addresses central aspects of history, politics, environment, and development, including gender relations, medicine, education, work, race, and class. No knowledge of Haitian Creole is required.

HAI 4905.course_description: For those who seek independent work not offered in another course. Must be arranged individually with Haitian faculty.

HAI 4911.course_description: Provides firsthand, supervised research in language, linguistics, literature, culture in Haitian Creole. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application.

HAT 3503.course_name: Haitian Culture and Literature in Translation
HAT 3503.course_description: Examines representations of Haiti and its culture through Haitian literature, art, film, and music.

HAT 3564.course_description: Addresses central aspects of history, politics, environment, and development, including attention to gender relations, medicine, education, work, race, and class. No knowledge of Haitian Creole is required.

HAT 3700.course_description: Examines the major sub-fields of linguistics by means of the Haitian Creole language. Introduces Haitian Creole syntax, morphology, phonology, semantics, and lexicon, as well as sociolinguistics, dialectology, language planning, bilingualism, and language contact.

HAT 4911.course_name: Undergraduate Research in English, Haitian Creole or French
HAT 4911.course_description: Provides firsthand, supervised research. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application in some combination of English, Haitian Creole or French.

HBR 1130.course_description: Beginning Hebrew covers four skills: listening, speaking, reading, and writing. For those with no prior exposure to the language.

HBR 4905.course_description: Individual work on an approved topic.

HBR 4930.course_description: Proseminar of variable content providing an opportunity for in-depth study of special topics in Israeli literature, history, or culture.

HBT 3223.course_name: Identity and Dissent in the Hebrew Short Story
HBT 3223.course_description: Traces the tension between the individual and the collective in Zionist/Israeli society over the last 100-plus years as illustrated in Hebrew short fiction.

HBT 3233.course_name: Israeli History and the Contemporary Novel
HBT 3233.course_description: Studies Israeli history through the lens of the contemporary novel.

HFT 2750.course_description: An overview of the meetings, conventions, special events and expositions industry.

HFT 3834.course_name: Entrepreneurship in Tourism, Hospitality and Event Management
HFT 3834.course_description: Analyzes the entrepreneurial opportunities in tourism, hospitality, recreation, events and sport by examining the process of creating, planning and managing business ventures in these sectors.

HFT 4446C.course_name: GIS and Spatial Analysis for Tourism and Social Data
HFT 4446C.course_description: Utilizes the opportunities provided by dynamically developing methods of geographical information systems (GIS) for visualization and geographic analysis of the data. Students will learn basic skills in working with the industry-standard ESRI ArcGIS software and apply their newly acquired knowledge in solving model problems in tourism research, planning, and development.

HFT 4746.course_name: Smart Cities, Attractions, and Theme Parks
HFT 4746.course_description: Provides the foundation needed to design smart tourism places. Examines relationships between technology, traveler behavior, and the travel industry. Learn to integrate technology, analytics, marketing, and the design of tourism cities, attractions, and theme parks. Focuses on sustainable/safe/healthy environments with cutting-edge technologies including Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Data Science.

HIN 4930.course_description: Variable topics dealing with specific issues in and in-depth study of prose or poetic genres in Hindi and/or Urdu. Supplementary critical readings in English.

HIS 3454.course_name: Racial Theories in Europe and the US
HIS 3454.course_description: Introduces history of racial ideas and images from ancient to modern period.

HIS 3460.course_description: Surveys the interaction between the religious and scientific communities in the West from the time of the early church to the present.

HIS 3463.course_name: Introduction, History of Science: Origins to Newton
HIS 3463.course_description: Introduces the emergence of scientific thought from its mythopoeic beginnings to the time of Newton. Focuses on the interrelationships among science, philosophy, and religion in Greece, Islam, and the Latin West. Emphasizes Copernicus, Kepler, Galileo, Descartes, and Newton.

HIS 3464.course_name: Introduction, History of Science: Renaissance to the Present
HIS 3464.course_description: General survey of the major issues in physical and biological science from the time of Galileo to the present. Emphasizes the impact of scientific development on society, culture, and thought.

HIS 3465.course_description: Emergence of modern science from Copernicus to Newton exploring the notions of empiricism, experiment, mechanism, materialism, and the historical concepts of continuity, change, revolution, and progress.

HIS 3483.course_description: History of the changing perception of the political and social significance of science since the discovery of nuclear fission.

HIS 3610.course_description: Examines the role of historical analysis and argument in the policy-making process. Introduces the ways in which decision-makers use and misuse history, and considers what it means to take history into account in public policy. Uses specific contemporary policy problems to illustrate the challenges of using history effectively.

HIS 4472.course_name: History of Evolutionary Thought from the Enlightenment to the Present
HIS 4472.course_description: Advanced history of science examines the history of evolutionary thought from the Enlightenment to the present. Emphasizes the specific development of Darwinian evolutionary theory and the lives of key theorists such as Charles Darwin and Alfred Russel Wallace. Considers sociopolitical and national contexts.

HIS 4911.course_description: Provides firsthand, supervised research. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application.

HIS 4944.course_name: Internship in the Practice of History
HIS 4944.course_description: Gives history majors practical experience in history-related institutions and organizations, such as archives, historical societies, museums and university presses.

HNG 1130.course_description: This course and its sequel, HNG 1131, constitute the basic sequence in Hungarian.

HNG 1180.course_description: Alternative to HNG 1130, for students who have some experience in Hungarian. Reviews basic grammar and improves reading, writing and listening skills.

HNG 1182.course_description: An accelerated one-semester coverage of HNG 1130 and HNG 1131 for students with some experience in Hungarian.

HOS 2333.course_description: For those interested in learning and reflecting upon the major future challenges of food and agriculture. Learn about postharvest biology, environmental and food sciences, and communication technology in reducing food waste.

HOS 3281C.course_description: Concepts and techniques of organic and sustainable production of horticultural crops, including soil/water management, pest control, harvest, handling, and marketing.

HOS 4905.course_description: Selected research topics in molecular biology, physiology, and/or genetics of horticultural crops.

HOS 4932.course_description: Critical review of selected topics in specific areas not covered in other horticultural sciences courses.

HOS 4933.course_description: Professional skills development, including job searching, resume writing, interview skills, professional etiquette, communications, and salary negotiations.

HPS 3003.course_description: Explores the different ways that scientists and mathematicians since the 17th century have explained the workings of the natural world.

HSC 3102.course_description: Surveys personal health concerns: emotional health; aging and death; alcohol, tobacco and drug abuse; physical fitness; nutrition and dieting; consumer health; chronic and communicable diseases; human sexuality; and environmental health.

HSC 4008.course_name: Professional Development for the Health Sciences
HSC 4008.course_description: Fosters the professional development needed to transition into the health and public health professions. Enrichment activities include diversity training, presentation skills training, career planning, and developing an online portfolio.

HSC 4133.course_description: Emphasizes content, issues, methodology and materials for the study of human sexuality. Prepares students to educate individuals and groups.

HSC 4134.course_description: Introduces theories of emotional well-being and health education, and the means of incorporating positive mental health practices into the health education programming and health counseling.

HSC 4174.course_name: Behavioral and Environmental Determinants of Obesity
HSC 4174.course_description: Explores interactions among individual, behavioral and environmental determinants of obesity. Focuses on the extent of the obesity problem primarily in the US from an epidemiological perspective. Ideas for prevention and control are discussed along with effective interventions to address obesity (policy development and implementation).

HSC 4247.course_description: Traces the interplay of misinformation and disinformation and the impact on personal and public health in the United States. Imparts understanding of the real world impact of misinformation on health outcomes and what can be done about it. Knowledge gained can be used to help understand how people are misinformed and lay the groundwork for being better informed future practitioners. Provides strategies to engage with people those influenced by misinformation or disinformation.

HSC 4593.course_description: Seminar examines the medical, social, legal and educational implications of HIV/AIDS on individuals and society. Includes lectures, guest and student presentations, videos and student-initiated discussions. Local, state and national experts in the fields of medicine, epidemiology, law, education and health promotion provide lectures.

HSC 4912.course_description: Provides health education and behavior undergraduates the opportunity to engage in supervised research. For this purpose, research is defined as an independent or team participatory experience that provides an opportunity to systematically investigate an existing or emerging health problem and to communicate the results of their work to others.

HSC 4930.course_description: Special topics in health science. Refer to the department for specific topic information. Can be repeated with change in content for up to 12 credits.

HSC 4969.course_name: Honors Seminar in the Health Professions
HSC 4969.course_description: Philosophy and implementation of scientific work, including an introduction to faculty research. Provides the opportunity to explore and discuss potential honors thesis topics.

HUM 1300.course_description: Students will explore the historical, theoretical, and cultural roots of compassion – or how people respond through empathetic action. Works of art, music, performing arts, literature, philosophy, religion, and history will help students critically reflect on the role of compassion within the human experience including quality of life and citizenship.

HUM 2420.course_description: Similar in philosophy and purpose to the basic sequence, with content selected from the philosophies, literature, arts, and music of various African countries and regions.

HUM 2930.course_description: Variable topics course exploring the interaction between various arts and between the arts and other disciplines.

HUM 3523.course_description: Review music therapy and music in health research to assess, orally and in scholarly writing, how music can be utilized to enhance well-being, the intersections between music and psychology/cognition/human behavior, as well as health maintenance issues and medical challenges of performing artists.

HUM 4930.course_description: An upper division general fine arts special/rotating topics on various subjects in the arts.

HUN 4905.course_description: Individual research work in various phases of human nutrition.

HUN 4936.course_description: Lectures or laboratory covering selected topics in human nutrition.

IDC 3500C.course_description: Introduces understanding interactivity as an art form, providing an in-depth exploration of the tools, theories and applications of interactive media as they are used for creative inquiry, research and production.

IDH 1700.course_description: Develop Career Related Skills to Succeed At Uf and Beyond.

IDH 2931.course_description: Special topics restricted to those in the university-wide Honors Program. (WR)

IDH 3931.course_description: Special topics restricted to those in the university-wide honors program.

IDH 4715.course_description: Helps select undergraduate students identify and compete for the most prestigious career-making scholarships by determining the activities and ideas most important and attractive to selection committees.

IDH 4903.course_description: Must be taken in conjunction with other courses at the 3000 and 4000 level. Students must secure instructor permission of the course to which they wish to add this credit.

IDH 4905.course_description: Restricted to those in the university-wide honors program.

IDS 1054.course_name: Introduction to Research in the Liberal Arts and Sciences
IDS 1054.course_description: Helps Liberal Arts and Sciences students find research opportunities and acquire skills. Topics include formulating research questions, drafting project proposals, cultivating professional relationships with faculty, presenting at conferences, and getting published. Students also engage with the wider research community through tours of special collections and QA sessions with faculty and undergraduate researchers.

IDS 1107.course_description: Provides incoming Innovation Academy students strategies for success as 21st century college students and innovators and equips students with the tools to become independent thinkers and learners.

IDS 1161.course_description: Examines the enduring question, "What is the Good Life?", from the perspectives of the humanities. Topics include the cost of the good life, how people have chosen to live as members of local and global communities, and conceptions and expressions of beauty, power, love, and health.

IDS 1307.course_name: Writing Life: Art, Drama, Film, Literature, Poetry, and You
IDS 1307.course_description: Examines how humanities-based texts (novels, films, plays, poems, and art) reflect and resonate with components of our personal, social, and cultural identities. To demonstrate your understanding of the course and its goals, you will write three essays and sit for two closed-book exams.

IDS 1624.course_description: Conceptualizing and representing the experience of time. Perspectives from history, cultural anthropology, literature, film, and art. Students analyze how enculturated understandings of time shape language, experience, and identity.

IDS 2334.course_description: Cross-disciplinary exploration of the intersection between the science of chemistry and the culture of the Spanish-speaking world. Studies the chemical reactions inherent in cooking while considering the role of food in the development and maintenance of culture. Active learning in laboratory and kitchen settings enhance the course content.

IDS 2338.course_description: Reflections on the concept of citizenship  in the US and internationally. Learn to analyze and to solve public problems and effectively evaluate methods of civic activism. (S)

IDS 2935.course_description: Introduces selected interdisciplinary topics. Content varies from term to term.

IDS 4911.course_description: Provides firsthand, supervised research in Interdisciplinary Studies. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application in Interdisciplinary Studies.

IDS 4930.course_description: Advanced study of selected topics. Content varies from term to term.

IDS 4940.course_description: Supervised internship under guidance of faculty member or delegated authority. Post-internship written report is required.

IHS 3102.course_description: Consistent/continual personal and professional growth is the core to preparation for health career professions. Offers pre-health students opportunities for analysis, engagement, and assessment of intrapersonal, interpersonal and critical reasoning preprofessional competencies defined by healthcare professional schools. Creation of professional development plan and professional school ‘application portfolio’ demonstrate knowledge, skills and qualifications needed for competitive applicants.

IHS 4950.course_description: Personal/professional development in interpersonal, intrapersonal, and thinking/reasoning skills, as well as knowledge of healthcare professional application content and process is imperative for successful admission to healthcare professional schools. Through engagement and reflection, PHPB students complete personal assessment and reflection to acquire in-depth knowledge of the application, complete personal/professional growth plan and application portfolio.

IND 3311C.course_description: Explores the power of color in our human experience and examination of the art and science of color theory in the context of interior design and allied fields.

IND 3627.course_description: Provides an understanding of sustainable interior environments. Introduces best practices, current trends, and case studies in various interior settings. Explores key elements of sustainability including environmental history, indoor sustainable development, waste management, energy consumption, and water conservation.

IND 3905.course_description: Special areas of study in interior design adjusted to the needs of the individual student.

INR 4905.course_description: Readings and discussion in advanced topics in International Relations.

INR 4911.course_description: Provides firsthand, supervised research. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application.

INS 3004.course_description: Demographics, cultures, governments and histories of major world regions as these relate to major, current, transnational and global issues such as migration, socio-economic development, conflicts and disasters, and environmental issues.

INS 4911.course_description: Provides an opportunity to undertake supervised research. Self-directed research allows individuals or groups to explore interesting issues in international studies and communicate their results.

IPM 4114.course_description: Covers the principles and practices used in pest and vector management, and also emphasizes the arthropod pests affecting crop and ornamental plants, humans and livestock.

ISC 1010C.course_description: Multi-disciplinary exploration of the history of alchemy, the precursor to modern chemistry. Studies the multi-dimensional relationships with philosophy, religion, and the natural sciences from antiquity to the modern era. Recreation of alchemical recipes in the teaching lab enhance the course content.

ISC 3523C.course_description: The tools scientists use to solve scientific problems, including use of experiments to answer scientific questions, design of experiments to reduce systematic and random errors, use of statistics to interpret experimental results and deal with sampling errors, mathematical modeling of scientific phenomena and oral presentation of scientific work.

ISM 3254.course_description: Introduces the basic tools for building business systems using object-oriented and event-driven programming paradigms. Emphasizes using Java to illustrate these ideas.

ISM 4113.course_description: Conceptual foundations of the process, data and object oriented approaches for the analysis and design of business systems. Systems development life cycle, rapid application design, CASE tools also covered.

ISM 4220.course_description: Various aspects of telecommunication systems, the use of local and wide area networks, the Internet, wireless technologies and distributed systems for decision making and strategic management questions relating to business goals, long-range planning and budgeting.

ISM 4930.course_description: Variable content provides an opportunity for in-depth study of topics not offered in other courses and of topics of special current significance.

ITA 1130.course_description: ITA 1130 and its sequel, ITA 1131, constitute the basic sequence in Italian. Emphasis on the development of broad competence in the language. Oral-aural approach ensures competence in the four skills.

ITA 4905.course_description: For advanced minors who seek independent work not offered in another course. Must be arranged individually with Italian faculty. Only three credits can count toward the minor.

ITA 4911.course_name: Undergraduate Research in Language or History/Culture in Italian
ITA 4911.course_description: Provides firsthand, supervised research. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application.

ITT 2530.course_description: Study of modern Italian narrative and its adaptation to film by major Italian directors.

ITT 3431.course_description: Through lectures, readings, and discussions, considers the continuing presence of Rome and other Italian cities as metaphors and focal points of Italian artistic and literary sensibilities. Taught in English.

ITT 3443.course_description: Exploration of Dante’s Inferno and the political, historical, and religious context in which Dante composed this canonical work of Italian and world literature. Taught in English.

ITT 3521.course_description: Critical and historical study of Italian film and directors. Topics may vary.

ITT 3930.course_name: Special Topics in Italian Literature and Culture
ITT 3930.course_description: Selected topics in Italian literature, civilization and culture, including crossover influence of media. Can focus on one epoch's influence on another.

ITT 4911.course_name: Undergraduate Research in Italian in English Translation
ITT 4911.course_description: Provides firsthand, supervised research. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application.

ITW 4580.course_name: Animals and Animality in Italian Culture
ITW 4580.course_description: Presentation and exploration of the figure of the nonhuman animal in the work of several modern Italian authors and poets. Analysis addresses the literary dimension of the selected animal portraits as well as any philosophical and ethical questions raised by these literary animals. Taught in Italian.

ITW 4911.course_name: Undergraduate Research in Literature in Italian
ITW 4911.course_description: Provides firsthand, supervised research in Literature in Italian. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application in Literature in Italian.

JOU 2100.course_description: Explore the differences of writing for the ear vs. writing for the eye. Focuses on storytelling through methodologies traditionally associated with broadcast journalism—which can also be incorporated in digital and social storytelling. Examines story structures and practical experience in writing scripts and sound-based stories.

JOU 3002.course_description: Overview of the nature of media audiences and their behaviors, as well as industry measurement practices and applications.

JOU 3110.course_description: Instruction and practice in researching and solving complex news problems. Emphasizes enterprise, documentation and use of multiple sources, using standard reference works and public records.

JOU 3363.course_name: Introduction to Web Apps for Communicators
JOU 3363.course_description: Introduces web markup, coding, and programming for journalism and communications students with no prior coding experience. Explore media-industry best practices for front-end web development, problem solving and algorithmic thinking, and recent examples of interactives and apps from media organizations.

JOU 3365.course_name: Artificial Intelligence in Media and Society
JOU 3365.course_description: Gain an understanding of artificial intelligence as it applies to the media professions, including journalists reporting on AI. Explore developments in AI technologies as covered by the mass media. Learn to detect exaggeration in descriptions of AI’s promise and potential risks and dangers.

JOU 3366C.course_description: Learn to develop strategy and execute tactics on social media platforms and social media accounts used by news organizations and individuals in professional contexts; write individual posts for various purposes and goals; produce photos, videos, and graphics for social sharing.

JOU 3920.course_description: Explores both traditional job-seeking methods as well as digital job hunting. Covers best practices in how to prepare for an interview and how to reach out to and search for employers online.

JOU 4004.course_description: Origin, development, and potentiality of print and broadcast media. Analyzes the evolution of standards, policies, methods, and controls.

JOU 4201.course_description: Creating and editing local news content in the College of Journalism and Communications’ professional news center for broadcast and digital platforms serving north central Florida; emphasizes news judgement that serves the audience.

JOU 4604.course_description: Primary concern is portfolio-quality single story-telling pictures and multiple picture packages, including picture stories. Introduces computer page layout. Deadline pressure emphasized; overview of picture editor duties; trends; social implications; portfolio preparation. Assignments involve computer programs. Students furnish supplies, most 35mm camera equipment and flash.

JOU 4700.course_name: Problems and Ethics of Journalism in Society
JOU 4700.course_description: Reading, analysis, and planning in current and projected issues in journalism, both in their professional and societal aspects.

JOU 4714.course_description: This course examines the relationship of sports and media and how it reinforces social values and sometimes challenges social norms. It also spotlights issues involving sports, race, gender, religion, sex and sexuality; how matters related to race, criminal justice, politics, patriotism, militarism, etc., affect mass perceptions of athletes; and stories of athletes who not only have overcome adversity, but also used their public role to advocate for broader social justice and self-determination.

JOU 4930.course_description: Variable content provides opportunity for study in academic areas of journalism, such as the literature of journalism and other fields within the province of the college.

JPN 1130.course_description: Beginning study covering four skills: listening, speaking, reading, and writing.

JPN 4905.course_description: For those who seek independent work not offered in another course. Available only by special arrangement.

JPN 4911.course_name: Undergraduate Research in Language or Linguistics
JPN 4911.course_description: Provides firsthand, supervised research in Language or Linguistics. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application in Language or Linguistics.

JPN 4930.course_description: Variable topics dealing with specific issues in and in-depth study of special topics in Japanese studies.

JPT 3100.course_description: An investigation of literary texts from the 8th through the 17th centuries presented within the framework of Western literary and feminist criticism.

JPT 3120.course_description: Critical examination of stories, autobiographies, and secondary criticism from the 19th century to the present. Become familiar with the forms and topics of criticism through Japanese and Western sources.

JPT 3140.course_description: Examination of narratives written by women who published during the Taisho (1912-25), Showa (1925-89) and Heisei (1989 to present) periods.

JPT 3150.course_description: Historical survey of traditional Japanese poetry (waka) from the 8th to the 16th century.

JPT 3330.course_description: Surveys Japanese literature of the Early Modern period (also called the Edo period), 1600-1868. Introduces and analyzes historically significant, foundational works of Early Modern Japanese literature and theater. Explores the history of the period and the development of print technologies and new genres, and introduces critical aesthetic and cultural concepts.

JPT 3500.course_description: Introduction to Japanese culture with emphasis on tracing the origin and development of important aspects of Japanese literature, art, religion, and society. All readings in English.

JPT 3521.course_description: Analysis of the meaning and significance of monstrous creatures and the genre of horror in premodern and modern Japan. Mixed-media content including mythology, performance and visual arts, fiction, graphic novels, and film. Canonical Western theory and content is included for contrast.

JPT 3702.course_description: Explores issues within Japanese visual culture, and uses visual-cultural products to explore Japanese political, cultural, social, and historical issues. Introduces and analyzes historically significant, foundational works of Japanese visual culture, unpacks genre and genre tropes in contemporary works, and analyzes several visual-cultural works that tackle significant social issues.

JPT 4130.course_description: Investigation of the 11th-century masterpiece and its pervasive influence on Japanese literature, past and present.

JPT 4502.course_description: Study of native belief systems and the supernatural as reflected in the folk practice of ritual observance and in tales, myths, songs, and proverbs.

JPT 4911.course_description: Provides firsthand, supervised research. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application.

JPW 4911.course_description: Provides firsthand, supervised research in Target Language. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application in Target Language.

JST 2841.course_description: Analyzes women's roles both as political agents and as objects of political policies and movements. Examines Israeli female politicians and judges as political actors, and as both subjects and objects of state policy.

JST 2930.course_description: Selected topics in the study of Jewish civilization.

JST 3821.course_description: Introduces major themes in dynamics of contemporary Israeli society. Juxtaposition of the different subjective points of view and motivations of the various actors involved.

JST 4905.course_description: For advanced students who desire supplemental reading or research under guidance.

KOR 1130.course_description: Beginning study covering speaking, listening, reading, writing, and cultural interaction.

LAA 1330.course_description: Inventory, analysis and evaluation of site development procedures; emphasis on landscape ecology.

LAA 1532.course_description: Explores the relationship between planning and design decision-making and landscape management practices which are, in turn, based on the fundamental principles of ecology and landscape ecology.

LAA 3230.course_description: Explores the theories pertinent to the practice and study of landscape architecture. Addresses primarily aesthetic and cultural principles and values with related ecological aspects.

LAA 3350C.course_description: Application of basic site design principles on small-scale projects.

LAA 4210.course_description: Preparation for professional practice and the understanding of the business of landscape architecture in private and public arenas.

LAA 4358.course_description: This final semester-long project expands personal interests and talents, hones decision-making abilities, and sharpens professional skills through well-rounded, comprehensive completion of individual projects. Project must be approved by the faculty.

LAA 4362.course_description: Immersive experience in visualization techniques in landscape architectural design and planning. Covers traditional drawing conventions (plan, section/elevation and perspective) and builds skills in digital communication and visualization methods.

LAA 4905.course_description: Studio investigations of topics in landscape architecture adjusted to individual needs of advanced undergraduate and graduate students.

LAA 4935.course_description: Assessment and discussion of works of landscape architecture with emphasis on user evaluation, design trends, and research directions. Open to all majors.

LAE 3005.course_description: Introduces genres of children's literature, critical response theory, strategies for critically evaluating books for instructional and aesthetic purposes, and strategies for generating personal, critical and aesthetic responses to literature from diverse and inclusive student populations.

LAE 4314.course_description: Analysis of content, materials, and methods for teaching language arts in an inclusive elementary school classroom.

LAH 3100.course_description: The last phase of the colonial regime, movement for independence, and problems of nation-building to the end of the 19th century.

LAH 3130.course_description: Surveys the formation of Spanish and Portuguese imperial systems and colonial societies in America in the 16th, 17th and 18th centuries.

LAH 3300.course_description: Contemporary challenges to traditional structures; revolution and evolution.

LAH 3470.course_description: The main issues and debates in Caribbean history from the time of Columbus to the mid-20th century.

LAH 3725.course_name: Race, Religion, and Revolution in the Black Caribbean
LAH 3725.course_description: Explores the history of Jamaica, Haiti, the Dominican Republic and the Miskito Coast of Nicaragua. Explains the emergence of colonial and neo-colonial political systems, the concept of race in relationship to slavery and global capitalism as well as the role of religion in revolutionary actions.

LAH 3741.course_description: Historical analysis of the armed and unarmed revolutionary movements of 20th century Latin America, from Mexico to Chile.

LAH 3931.course_name: Special Topics in Latin American History
LAH 3931.course_description: Selected, variable topics in the history and culture of Latin America.

LAH 4433.course_description: Aftermath of independence and war with US, the Reform and Maximillian, Porfiriato, Mexican Revolution and contemporary trends.

LAH 4471.course_description: Social, economic and political history of the West Indies and the Circum-Caribbean region to 1800, with particular emphasis on slave society.

LAH 4472.course_name: The Caribbean, Nineteenth and Twentieth Centuries
LAH 4472.course_description: Social history of the modern Caribbean: slave emancipation and decolonization; race relations and black consciousness; labor, culture, and economic change.

LAH 4602.course_description: Historical analysis of the Amazon. Need no previous knowledge of Latin American history; for those interested in the current issues confronting the region.

LAH 4630.course_description: Late and colonial reform; independence and origins and achievements of Brazilian monarchy; modernization and neo-colonialism; slavery, the military, and emergence of oligarchical republic; legacy of dictatorship and populism.

LAH 4730.course_name: Science and Technology in Latin American, 1492-Present
LAH 4730.course_description: Introduces the diffusion, acculturation and adaption of scientific ideas, practices and technology by exploring concepts within Latin America.

LAS 3040.course_name: Drug Wars and Oil Fortunes in Latin America
LAS 3040.course_description: Examines the historical, comparative, and current dynamics of two global commodities—illicit drugs and licit petroleum. Considers how the presumably separate spheres of legal and illegal commodity exchange have become intertwined and covers the linkages between the Drug War, petroleum extractivism, and United States—Latin America relations.

LAS 3930.course_name: Special Topics in Latin American Studies
LAS 3930.course_description: Variable topics in Latin American studies.

LAS 4911.course_name: Undergraduate Research in Latin American Studies
LAS 4911.course_description: Course provides firsthand, supervised research in Latin American Studies. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application in Latin American Studies.

LAS 4935.course_description: Multidisciplinary variable topics seminar. Required of all candidates for the undergraduate certificate and minor in Latin American studies. (WR)

LAT 1130.course_description: This course and its sequel, LAT 1131, constitute the basic sequence for development of overall skill in the language. Students are expected students to have little or no background in Latin. Others enrolling in the course will be required to take it for an S/U grade.

LEI 3301.course_description: Overview of the travel and tourism industry; covers historical, behavioral, societal, and business aspects of travel and tourism.

LEI 3303.course_description: Examines the planning of tourism services and facilities, including the identification, planning and use of the physical, social and economic resources necessary to develop and support tourism.

LEI 3360.course_description: Overview of the hospitality industry, including hotel management, food and beverage operations, business and leisure travel markets, convention services, hospitality trends, quest-based customer service strategies and career opportunities.

LEI 4540.course_name: Management & and Supervision of THEM Facilities
LEI 4540.course_description: The management process as it relates to planning and operation of leisure service facilities. Subjects include traditional and contemporary management theory, the management process, legal and financial aspects, risk management and contemporary issues in leisure services management. Facility topics include feasibility studies and design issues.

LEI 4905.course_description: Offered upon request to meet special interests not adequately provided in other courses, such as Multidisciplinary Perspectives of Gerontology and Health and Physical Aspects of Aging.

LEI 4912.course_description: Participate in supervised research experiences. For this purpose, research is defined as an independent, self-directed experience that enables the investigation of an issue in tourism, hospitality, event management and other leisure settings and then to communicate the results to others.

LEI 4940.course_description: Practical field experience in selected off-campus tourism, hospitality, and event service agencies. Normally taken during the last semester before graduation.

LEI 4941.course_name: Practicum in Tourism, Hospitality and Event Management
LEI 4941.course_description: Provides practical experience for Tourism, Hospitality and Event Management majors who will maintain part-time work in an approved setting appropriate to their specialization.

LIN 1140.course_description: Interdisciplinary study of the interface of emotion and language. Focus on vocal properties of emotion expression, how different languages conceptualize emotion, how those who are not neurotypical may differ in the expression of emotion, and implications of gender-differential expectations of emotion expression for self-presentation.

LIN 2004.course_description: Broad survey of the world’s languages, their genetic affiliations, and current status. Addresses issues related to linguistic diversity and provides an overview of the major subfields of linguistics by acquainting students with linguistic properties of diverse languages and language families.

LIN 2614.course_description: Focuses on linguistic diversity in the US, touching on American dialects, multilingualism in America, Native American languages, and sociolinguistic variation. Dialect analysis tools will be learned and applied in class projects.

LIN 3010.course_description: Core areas of linguistics research: phonology, morphology, syntax, semantics, sociolinguistics, and language acquisition.

LIN 3710.course_description: Child language development and use as it influences classroom practice and literacy development. Study of oral language development of children from birth through age eight.

LIN 4911.course_description: Provides firsthand, supervised research in linguistics. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application in linguistics.

LIT 3031.course_description: Variable topics provide in-depth study of genre such as the lyric, epic, or sonnet, or of developments in periods of literature such as the medieval, American, or African. Emphasizes refining the ability to read and analyze texts carefully and accurately. Refer to department website for offered topics.

LIT 3041.course_description: Variable topics provide an in-depth study of genre such as comedy or tragedy, or of developments in periods such as the Elizabethan, Jacobean, or Restoration. Refer to department website for offered topics.

LIT 3043.course_description: Representative selections from continental, British, and American playwrights. Refer to department website for offered topics.

LIT 3173.course_description: Variable topics in the Jewish literary experience, from the biblical narrative and classical tales to Yiddish and Hebrew literature, the modern European novel, and American Jewish fiction.

LIT 3362.course_description: Examines the revolutionary experimentalist aspects of modern and contemporary culture, such as cubism, surrealism, structuralism, and conceptualism.

LIT 3374.course_description: Literary analysis from the Hebrew and Christian Bibles with an emphasis on poetry and narrative.

LIT 3383.course_description: Critical and thematic study of women in literature that may include fiction, poetry, or drama in English, American, or world literature. Refer to department website for offered topics.

LIT 3400.course_description: Interdisciplinary variable-topics study of the vital relationship between literature and other creative arts, other humanistic disciplines, or the sciences and technology. Refer to department website for offered topics.

LIT 4188.course_description: Variable topics focus on one or more of the diverse English language literary traditions, including those of Ireland, Scotland, India, Nigeria, the Caribbean, Canada, and Australia. Refer to department website for offered topics.

LIT 4192.course_description: Variable topics focus on the critical and analytical study of representative Caribbean authors writing in English. Refer to department website for offered topics.

LIT 4194.course_description: Critical and analytical study of representative Black-African authors writing in English, notably Achebe, Awoonor, Ngugi, Aidoo, Soyinka, Armah, Ekwensi, Mphalele, and p'Bitek'.

LIT 4305.course_description: Variable topics provide an opportunity for the in-depth study of comics genres, notable comics writers, and illustrators and other significant topics on related subjects.

LIT 4322.course_description: Reading folktales, myths, and legends, particularly those told orally by ethnic, indigenous, and emigrant cultures within the USA. Attention is paid to critical theory and the scholarly study of the folktale. In addition, the use of the folktale by creative writers and teachers is discussed.

LIT 4332.course_description: Explores kinds and qualities of literature for the younger child, examining the child's first experience with literature in oral forms, then moving on to picture and story books and poetry.

LIT 4334.course_description: Origins and evolution of the Anglo-American tradition in literature for young readers, 1720-1920, with an emphasis on the Victorian era. Authors may include Defoe, Scott, Cooper, Dickens, Alcott, Twain and Stevenson.

LIT 4930.course_name: Variable Topics in Literature and Language
LIT 4930.course_description: Proseminar of variable content providing an opportunity for the in-depth study of various topics, such as the literature of war and peace, of death and of courtly love. Refer to department website for offered topics.

LNW 3220.course_description: Readings from Petronius, Apuleius or the Historia Apollonii Regis Tyri.

LNW 3310.course_description: Translation and analysis of the comedies of Plautus and Terence or the tragedies of Seneca.

LNW 3360.course_description: Translation and analysis of the Roman satirists Horace, Persius, Juvenal, or Martial.

LNW 3380.course_description: Readings in Latin from one of the Roman historians: Sallust, Caesar, Livy, or Tacitus.

LNW 3660.course_description: Translation and analysis of selections from Vergil's Aeneid in the light of his epic techniques and the spirit of the Augustan Age.

LNW 4911.course_name: Undergraduate Research in Latin Language and Literature
LNW 4911.course_description: Provides firsthand, supervised research. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application.

MAC 3472.course_description: Topics covered in the MAC 3472/MAC 3473/MAC 3474 sequence closely parallel those covered in MAC 2311/MAC 2312/MAC 2313, but are treated in greater depth. Credit will be given for, at most, MAC 2311 or MAC 3472.

MAE 2364.course_name: Explorations Teaching Secondary Mathematics and Science
MAE 2364.course_description: Introduces prospective teachers to teaching secondary mathematics and science (grades 6-12).

MAE 3312.course_description: Analysis of the content and methods necessary to effectively teach content from the number, algebra, and geometry strands of mathematics in the inclusive elementary classroom. Provides pre-service teachers with the underlying content and pedagogical content knowledge necessary to effectively teach mathematics.

MAE 4310.course_name: Teaching Mathematics in the Inclusive Elementary School
MAE 4310.course_description: Analyzes content, materials and methods of teaching mathematics in the inclusive elementary classroom. Prepares the future teacher of mathematics for facilitation of instruction to meet the needs of all children, including children with disabilities.

MAN 4930.course_description: Variable content provides an opportunity for study in-depth of topics not offered in other courses and of topics of special current significance.

MAN 7852.course_description: This course will build from the student’s basic knowledge of regression analysis, validity and reliability. It will introduce modeling of latent variables with confirmatory factor analysis, and assessment of the validity evidence for the hypothesized factor model. Then, it will introduce the estimation of the structural relationships between latent variables using structural equation modeling, including mediation and moderation.

MAR 2951.course_description: Projects related to business in marketing as approved by the college.

MAR 4905.course_description: Opportunity for in-depth study not offered in other courses.

MAR 4933.course_description: Selected rotating topics in marketing management, research and theory.

MAT 4911.course_description: Provides firsthand, supervised research in mathematics. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application in mathematics.

MAT 4930.course_description: Qualified undergraduates take part in seminars or classes on special topics.

MCB 2000.course_description: Role of microorganisms in chemical transformations, disease, public health, and agriculture. Fundamental concepts are discussed, followed by beneficial and harmful actions of microorganisms as they affect our lives. Not acceptable for admission to advanced microbiology courses nor for the preprofessional curricula required for the medical/veterinary sciences.

MCB 3703.course_description: Examines the origin, evolution, and future of life in our solar system. Include planetary habitability, astrobiogeochemistry, microbial life, and human spaceflight.

MCB 4091.course_name: Innovation Project Management for Life Sciences
MCB 4091.course_description: Provides practical tools to manage innovation projects typical of life science research and development. Discusses challenges and methodologies associated with developing objectives, preparing project plans, establishing metrics, defining responsibilities, as well as mitigating risks and dealing with uncertainties. Also strengthens skills for strategic prioritization, time management, meeting facilitation, and communication to promote an innovative culture.

MCB 4911.course_name: Supervised Research in Microbiology and Cell Science
MCB 4911.course_description: Provides firsthand, supervised research. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application..

MCB 4934.course_name: Special Topics in Microbiology and Cell Science
MCB 4934.course_description: Supervised literature or historical study on current topics in microbiology and cell science. Not acceptable toward 25 credits of required department and elective credits.

MCB 4941.course_description: Internship in microbiology and cell science under supervision of the department.

MDU 4001.course_description: First of two courses of introduction to the medical sciences.

MDU 4002.course_description: The second course of introduction to the medical sciences.

MDU 4008.course_name: Aspects of the Art of Medicine
MDU 4008.course_description: Introduces the Essential Competencies Needed to Practice the Art of Medicine; Designed to Assist Third Year Students in the Medical Honors Program for Successful Transition to Uf College of Medicine. Provides Knowledge, Skills, and Experiences to Be Successful Personally and Professionally During Medical Education and Beyond.

MDU 4010.course_description: Cellular functions in health and disease. The structure and molecular biology of mammalian cells are stressed, including virus-cell interactions, inborn errors or metabolism and bacterial growth.

MDU 4051.course_description: Introductory course to the physical realities of patient care and to the way in which medical humanities illuminate understanding of the practice of medicine.

MEM 3300.course_name: Castles and Cloisters: An Introduction to Medieval Communities
MEM 3300.course_description: Studies monastic and courtly-chivalric communities as these evolved in the Middle Ages. Explores architecture, art, literature, and music illustrate how different monastic and chivalric communities saw the world and their place in it.

MEM 4905.course_name: Independent Study in Medieval and Early Modern Studies
MEM 4905.course_description: Independent work in medieval and early modern studies.

MET 4301.course_description: This course covers the forces that govern atmospheric motion; acceleration in rotating curvilinear coordinates; momentum, continuity, and energy equations; scale analysis; geostrophic, gradient, and thermal winds; natural coordinates; circulation and vorticity theorems; Reynolds stresses; Prandtl and Ekman layers; and developing baroclinic systems.

MET 4910.course_description: Completion of an honors thesis that meets department specifications during the semester in which the student is enrolled.

MET 4911.course_name: Undergraduate Research in Meteorology and Climatology
MET 4911.course_description: Provides firsthand, supervised research. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application.

MGF 1106.course_description: For non-science and non-business majors. Includes an introduction to set theory, logic, number theory, probability, statistics, graphing, and linear programming.

MGF 1107.course_description: Demonstrates the beauty and utility of mathematics through topics which include financial management, linear and exponential growth, mathematics in the arts, and discrete mathematics. Does not require MGF 1106.

MMC 1000.course_description: Introduces the various mass communication media, with special emphasis on their roles and responsibilities to society and the public.

MMC 1009.course_description: Introduces the tools, resources and academic and extra-curricular activities offered by the College of Journalism and Communications. Includes lessons on the history and organization of the college and academic and career preparation.

MMC 2121.course_description: One-third of the course is to ensure students have sufficient skill in grammar and punctuation to write with clarity. In two-thirds of the course, students put principles of good writing into practice with short writing assignments that have real-world applications.

MMC 2450.course_description: Numeracy which enables data literacy; to use, evaluate, and communicate numbers in situations commonly faced in advertising, journalism, public relations, and telecommunications.

MMC 2613.course_description: Covers intersection between news media and state/local government. Students will analyze how media interacts with societal power structures in ways that influence social and racial justice. Through analysis of investigative journalism and theories like agenda-setting and framing, students will learn how to use information to become more effective civic participants.

MMC 2740.course_description: Introduces sports professions relative to opportunities, responsibilities and current issues involving sports media professionals. Topics include distinctions among careers in sports media, including sports journalism and communications, values, ethics and issues related to race, gender and sexual orientation, and emerging media.

MMC 3260.course_description: History, development, and current state of online communications from teletext to the World Wide Web. Focuses on how online services relate to mass media in the past, present, and future. Analyzes content methods, audiences, and income sources. Create online projects related to mass communication.

MMC 3420.course_description: Provides practical analytical skill-sets, benefiting those who plan careers in analytics/research, social media, media business, advertising/marketing, and public relations.

MMC 3614.course_description: Provides an understanding of the role of the media in the political system. Topics include televised debates, political advertising, political journalism, internet, and alternative media.

MMC 3630.course_description: Explores the structure and consequences of the growing presence of social media networks. Addresses such areas as privacy, democracy, health care, commerce, entertainment, and journalism.

MMC 3703.course_description: Relationships between sports, athletes, media, and audience. Includes the evolution of sports media from the early sportswriters to the day when athletes control their own messages via Twitter. Covers the various mediums (newspapers, magazines, books, radio, TV, online, forums, blogs, and social media) in terms of their history, function, and impact.

MMC 4200.course_description: Understanding the law, which guarantees and protects the privileges and defines the responsibilities of the mass media. Includes problems of constitutional law, libel, privacy, and governmental regulations.

MMC 4302.course_description: Theoretical bases of world mass media systems, international channels of communications, analysis of press and broadcasting systems by regional and national categories.

MSL 4905.course_description: Readings and discussion in advanced topics of military science.

MUC 1211.course_description: Required for all majors in theory/composition. Workshop in composition techniques, exploring use of styles and devices of contemporary art music and presentation through the use of finale.

MUC 1212.course_description: Required for all majors in theory/composition. Workshop in composition techniques, exploring use of styles and devices of contemporary art music and presentation through the use of finale.

MUC 2101.course_description: Required for all majors in composition. Workshop in composition techniques, exploring use of styles and devices of contemporary art music and presentation through the use of finale.

MUC 2102.course_description: Required for all majors in composition. Workshop in composition techniques, exploring use of styles and devices of contemporary art music and presentation through use of finale.

MUC 3231.course_description: Composition in simple and extended forms supplemented by analysis of selected compositions, from the standard repertoire and presentation through the use of finale.

MUC 3232.course_description: Composition in simple and extended forms supplemented by analysis of selected compositions, from the standard repertoire and presentation through the use of finale.

MUC 4241.course_description: Composition in extended forms supplemented by analysis of selection compositions, from the standard repertoire and presentation through the use of finale.

MUC 4242.course_description: Composition in extended forms supplemented by analysis of selection compositions, from the standard repertoire and presentation through the use of finale.

MUC 4313.course_description: Survey of the techniques, history, literature and materials of electroacoustic music.

MUC 4401.course_description: Continuation of MUC 4313. Projects in electroacoustic music dealing with real-time, interactivity, live-electronic and solo digital media music composition issues.

MUC 4441.course_description: Continuation of skills developed through MUC 4401, Composition of Electroacoustic Music.

MUC 4442.course_description: Continuation of skills developed through MUC 4441, Electroacoustic Music Composition: Digital 1.

MUE 2430.course_description: Required of all music education majors. Basic technical competency and pedagogical technique for voice.

MUE 2440.course_description: Required of all music education majors. Basic technical competency and pedagogical techniques for the upper string instruments: violin/viola.

MUE 2442.course_description: Basic technical competency and pedagogical techniques for the lower string instruments: cello and double bass.

MUE 2450.course_description: Required of all music education majors. Basic technical competency and pedagogical techniques for clarinet and flute.

MUE 2452.course_description: Basic technical competency and pedagogical techniques for alto saxophone, bassoon and oboe.

MUE 2460.course_description: Required of all music education majors. Basic technical competency and pedagogical techniques for two brass instruments.

MUE 2462.course_description: Basic technical competency and pedagogical techniques for two brass instruments, other than those studied in MUE 3460.

MUE 2470.course_description: Required of all music education majors. Basic technical competency and pedagogical techniques for percussion instruments.

MUE 2471.course_description: Continuation of percussion teaching and performance skills.

MUE 3210.course_description: Helps meet state certification requirements for elementary classroom teachers. Function of elementary school music in aiding the developmental growth of children.

MUE 3311.course_description: Fundamental principles and procedures of music education in elementary school.

MUE 3330.course_description: Fundamental principles and procedures of music education in the secondary school.

MUE 3343.course_name: Materials and Methods of String Class Teaching
MUE 3343.course_description: The study of contemporary materials and methods suitable for use in public school string classes.

MUE 4422.course_description: Develop musical and pedagogical knowledge, skills, and dispositions essential for teaching elementary, middle school, and high school instrumental music. Field work in schools.

MUE 4480.course_description: Examination, evaluation and practical application of marching band techniques for the high school and college band director.

MUE 4940.course_description: Student teaching in selected classrooms of public schools. Special seminars and continuous evaluation of teaching experiences.

MUG 4104.course_description: Basic techniques of choral and instrumental conducting.

MUG 4202.course_description: Basic techniques of choral conducting, score analysis, interpretation and use of basic choral materials.

MUG 4302.course_description: Basic techniques of instrumental conducting, score analysis, interpretation and use of basic instrumental materials.

MUH 3025.course_name: Popular Music in the USA: From Ragtime to Hip-Hop and Beyond
MUH 3025.course_description: Surveys the musical styles, artists, audiences, and eras of American popular music in relation to the social, cultural, political, and historical contexts in which they emerged. Gives special attention to the diversity and intersecting nature of musical voices in the USA through the examination of musical styles including rock, rhythm and blues, country, punk, hip-hop, salsa, and beyond.

MUH 4016.course_description: From African, Latin American, and Black American sources through contemporary development.

MUH 4537.course_name: Jazz, Hip Hop, and African Connections
MUH 4537.course_description: Considers how African music and culture have influenced African American musical expression since the beginning of the transatlantic slave trade and up through the development of the blues, jazz, soul music, hip hop, and RB. Also considers how such cultural flows have moved in both directions, from the foundations of African American music in African aesthetics, to the ways that jazz and hip-hop musicians have made explicit reference or taken inspiration from Africa.

MUH 4930.course_description: Rotating topics of current or special interest to students or instructors.

MUL 4441.course_description: An intensive, investigative study of representative repertoire for woodwind instruments.

MUL 4442.course_description: An intensive, investigative study of standard repertoire for brass instruments.

MUL 4460.course_description: An intensive, investigative study of standard repertoire for solo percussion and percussion ensemble.

MUL 4600.course_name: History and Literature of Art Song
MUL 4600.course_description: Consists of lectures, discussion of reading assignments, listening to recordings of art song, group presentations of assigned topics, and exams. Class preparation includes reading portions of the text, listening, and readiness to discuss song/text analysis. Exams match composer to song or song cycle, fact to composer, short answer, listening, and essay. Offered in Miami only.

MUL 4602.course_description: The study and performance of representative literature for the voice from each style period.

MUL 4630.course_name: Symphonic Chamber Vocal Literature (Offered in Miami only)

MUN 1460.course_description: Examination and performance of standard repertoire for chamber ensembles.

MUN 3123.course_description: Performance of general and popular band literature.

MUN 3133.course_description: Performance of traditional and contemporary band literature.

MUN 3323.course_description: Vocal training and public performances of standard female chorus repertoire.

MUN 3333.course_description: Vocal training and public performance of standard male chorus repertoire.

MUN 3493.course_description: Rehearsal and performance of repertoire for small ensembles written in the 20th and 21st centuries.

MUN 3643.course_description: Offered in Miami only. Examination and performance of standard repertoire for the musical theatre.

MUN 4016.course_description: Ensemble of variable instrumentation and/or voices performing traditional and contemporary repertoire. For upper-division students who have completed required credits of ensemble participation or elective credits for their degree program, this ensemble exists to allow them to continue performing in ensembles without impacting semester load credits, or excess hours credits. This course allows students from any degree to continue participation in ensembles in support of the university.

MUN 4642.course_description: Provides an intermediate understanding of musical theatre instrumental styles and practices from the 1930s to the present. Incorporating one or more of these forms and techniques each semester, it’s recommended for musicians who would like to broaden their commercial repertoire and enhance their skills for professional engagements.

MUO 3503.course_description: Study and performance of works from opera and operetta.

MUO 3652.course_description: Study and performance of opera and music theatre repertoire through operatic and musical theatre ensembles: systematic approach to developing roles and honing of performance skills. Offered in Miami only.

MUR 3104.course_description: Examines the music of the Catholic Church from historical and artistic perspectives and presents issues that have surrounded major changes in the church's music. Focuses on six historical periods in which the church was significantly focused on musical developments or changes. Views the music from various cultural perspectives, primarily US and European.

MUS 1010.course_description: Attendance at concerts and recitals. Check the School of Music student's handbook for specific attendance requirements.

MUS 1360.course_description: Provides the fundamentals of music technology in the context of its historical and cultural use. Addresses scientific foundations of acoustics, hearing, and digital audio as well as technical skills for music production; students will work on practical applications of these concepts and techniques. Furthermore, the instructor will encourage students to critically explore cultural aspects of music technology.

MUS 1610.course_name: An Echo of the Invisible World: Exploring the Relationship Between Music & Spirituality
MUS 1610.course_description: Examines the relationship between music and spirituality, within and outside the context of organized religion. Consider the underlying philosophies in spiritual music and practices, compare them to contemporary American culture, and address their own beliefs and practices through selected case studies and projects.

MUS 2211.course_description: An English diction course for singers and choral directors to improve their capacity to respond with ease, accuracy and expression.

MUS 2241.course_description: An Italian diction course for singers and choral directors to improve their capacity to respond with ease, accuracy and expression.

MUS 4905.course_description: Individual work in music and music education.

MUS 4910.course_description: Individual guided research in music and music education.

MUT 1001.course_description: The study of notation, scales, intervals, triads, aural skills, and keyboard skills.

MUT 1111.course_description: Studies rhythms, intervals, motifs, phrases, melodies, chords and chord progressions, in the standard clefs through listening, playing, and writing. Chord study includes primary and secondary triads in root position and inversions, non-harmonic tones and seventh chords.

MUT 1112.course_description: Rhythms, intervals, motifs, phrases, melodies, chords and chord progressions, in the standard clefs through listening, playing, singing and writing. Chord study includes primary and secondary triads in root position and inversions, non-harmonic tones and diatonic seventh chords.

MUT 2116.course_description: Using Roman numerals, analyze harmonically the music of the common practice period; includes all harmonic materials studied to date such as Borrowed chords, Neapolitan 6th chords, and Augmented 6th chords. The study of forms from the 18th and 19th Centuries.

MUT 2117.course_description: The study of the materials and structures of tonal and post-tonal music through reading, listening, model composition, and music analysis.

MUT 3321.course_description: Study of voices and instruments, singly and by family, with basic scoring for standard ensemble combinations.

MUT 3322.course_description: Transcribing and arranging for full band and orchestra, including preparation of parts for performance.

MUT 3611.course_description: Analysis of melodic structures and homophonic forms of the common practice period including binary, ternary, rondo and sonata-allegro forms.

MUT 3612.course_description: Analysis of contrapuntal forms of canon, motet and fugue; study of musical forms in the 20th century.

MUT 3622.course_description: Engage with computational methods for the analysis and generation of musical materials and structures to better understand how humans produce and interact with them. Topics covered include music representation and encoding, music information retrieval, corpus studies, machine improvisation, and procedural music generation. These techniques will be considered in the context of many different aesthetics, styles, genres, theoretical frameworks, and societal contexts.

MUT 4401.course_description: Addresses the practice of two-voice counterpoint in Renaissance and Baroque styles with additional focus on historical context. Through composition, study, performance and listening, students gain fluency in both strict and free two-part counterpoint, compound melody, canon, antiphon and inventions.

MUT 4421.course_description: Counterpoint in the 18th-century style through listening, reading, playing, singing and writing.

MUT 4601.course_description: Score-reading at the keyboard. Exercises in realization of music in two or more staves and clefs, and involving instrumental transpositions.

MVB 4640.course_description: An analysis of the principles, methods and practices currently used in the teaching of brass instruments.

MVK 2221.course_description: This course is required of all music majors, with the exception of keyboard majors. Levels (3) and (4) may be exempted by examination.

MVK 2222.course_description: This course is required of all music majors, with the exception of keyboard majors. Levels (3) and (4) may be exempted by examination.

MVK 3702.course_description: Instrumental chamber music, song, orchestral reductions and editions.

MVK 4126.course_name: Improvisational Keyboard Skills and Related Technology
MVK 4126.course_description: Study of improvisational skills, electric keyboard technology, and musical styles outside of the classical realm.

MVK 4600.course_description: An analysis of the principles, methods and practices currently in the teaching of organ.

MVK 4640.course_description: An analysis of the principles, methods and practices currently used in the teaching of piano.

MVS 3436.course_description: Courses offered under the MVS 1416, 2426, 3436, 4446 heading are intended to teach intermediate through advanced study of classical guitar and are available only through the permission of the instructor. Lesson times will be arranged at the beginning of each semester.

MVS 4446.course_description: Courses offered under the MVS 1416, 2426, 3436, 4446 heading are intended to teach intermediate through advanced study of classical guitar and are available only through the permission of the instructor. Lesson times will be arranged at the beginning of each semester.

MVS 4640.course_description: An introduction to the teaching of basic string instrument techniques.

MVV 4640.course_description: An analysis of various methods, principles and practices in the teaching of voice.

MVW 4640.course_description: An analysis of the principles, methods and practices currently used in the teaching of woodwind instruments.

NEM 3002.course_description: Introduces nematology, including studies of morphology, life histories, and control of the major nematode parasites of plants. Also includes studies of the bionomics of certain soil nematodes and nematode parasites of vertebrates and arthropods.

NEM 4905.course_description: Selected problems for study, research, or discussion in nematology.

NGR 6870.course_description: The purpose of this course is to develop the nursing informatics knowledge and skills needed for the advanced practice nurse to optimize health information systems/technology to support communication, the delivery of high quality nursing care, patient outcomes, and the improvement of population health.

NSC 1101L.course_description: Drill, basic commands, courtesies and honors, orientation and information.

NSC 1140.course_description: US naval history from the Phoenicians to the present with emphasis on major developments. Included is an in-depth discussion of the geopolitical theory of Mahan. Discusses present-day concerns in sea-power and maritime affairs, including the economic and political issues of merchant marine commerce, the Navys involvement in liberation and terrorist movements overseas and the massive changes in the US Navy due to the breakup of the Soviet Union.

NSC 2102L.course_description: Drill, basic commands, courtesies and honors, orientation, and information.

NSC 2122.course_description: Introduction to the theory, characteristics and principles of operation of naval weapons systems. Includes coverage of types of weapons and fire control systems, capabilities and limitations, theory of target acquisition, identification and tracking, trajectory principles and basics of naval ordinance.

NSC 3103L.course_description: Practical exercises dealing with the specifics of naval organizations and leadership.

NSC 4104L.course_description: Practical exercises dealing with naval organizations and leadership.

NSC 4230.course_description: The principles of naval administration, stressing the experimental approach to learning the principles of leadership and management. The student develops skills in the areas of communication, counseling, control, direction, leadership and management functions and responsibilities through active, guided participation in naval-based case studies, experimental exercises and situational problems. Total quality leadership and professional responsibilities are included.

NSC 4905C.course_description: Readings, assignments, student presentations and discussions on naval science.

NUR 2650.course_name: Transcultural Communications in Health Care Today
NUR 2650.course_description: Broadens the perceptions and understanding of health care beliefs and practices of specific cultural groups in the United States; fosters the development of essential communication skills and techniques necessary for effective multidisciplinary teams and culturally sensitive practice.

NUR 3123.course_description: Increases understanding of cellular physiology and alterations in structure and function resulting from the action of stressors on the human body at the cellular level.

NUR 3169.course_name: Inquiry and Evidence in Professional Nursing Practice
NUR 3169.course_description: Examines the processes required to translate and to integrate evidence into nursing practice.

NUR 3826.course_name: Legal and Ethical Issues in Nursing
NUR 3826.course_description: Examines the legal issues and ethical dilemmas in nursing practice. Consequences of ethical misconduct and legal malpractice are explored. Focus is on case analysis of legal and ethical issues.

NUR 3946L.course_description: Additional opportunities for nursing practice. Objectives to be developed collaboratively by student and faculty.

NUR 4905.course_description: Individual study. Qualified students may choose particular issues for study.

NUR 4930.course_description: Prior to registration, students should contact the College of Nursing for special topics offered.

OCE 1001.course_description: Using the scientific method, critical thinking skills, and data analysis, this course will examine the fundamental processes of the ocean system, composed of an atmosphere, hydrosphere, lithosphere, and biosphere, through time. The course will also explore interactions between these spheres, including critical analysis of scientific theories and emphasize oceanic connections with humanity.

ORH 1283.course_description: Overview of the complexities of the orchid family, how selected genera are produced and the potential these plants offer to commercial nursery operators and hobbyists for profit or enjoyment.

ORH 2752.course_description: Hands-on, multidisciplinary approach to environmental horticulture delivered through the context of the human senses.
